titleStmt.title: INTERACTIVE INVESTIGATION of FLUID MECHANICS DATA SETS

analytic.title: INTERACTIVE INVESTIGATION of FLUID MECHANICS DATA SETS

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.head: INTRODUCTION
div.p: Today's fluid mechanics engineer has access to computational and experimental tools that generate enormous amounts of simulated and empirical data for problems under study.

Encoded within these huge raw data sets is the information and knowledge that the engineer is searching for. By employing computer graphics to enhance the interface between the user and their data, (i.e. allow interactive investigation of data), productivity in research and product development can be greatly increased. Edwards

div.head: [ Z ]
div.p: has visualization in scientific work: identified three applications of
As a diagnostic tool to test and validate scientific procedure:
As a research tool to interpret and understand physical phenomena:
As an effective tool for communicating scientific results. A numerical simulation of the effect of a hot streak in a two-dimensional time-dependent rotor-stator interaction [5];

An experimental LDV data set for the performance of a fuel injector FIELDVIEW is available on a variety of UNIX workstations and operates on data sets stored as NASA Plot3D grid and solution files, as well as other data formats.

It computes a variety of scalar and vector functions on the field data and represents the results as cutting planes, iso-surfaces, arrow fields, contour lines, and particle paths. Animation is used for time-dependent cases and parameter sweeping. Interface. In addition to accepting data from the previous stage in the pipeline, user input/control for each stage is shown to the right of each function block.
Function-specific output data is also indicated to the right of the particular function block.

Two types of input files are required: grid geometr (grid file) , which stores the X, Y, f coordinates of the grid points and flow quantities (solution file), which contains the experimental or computational results.
Access to the input parameters is provided by a graphical user interface, based on MOTIF.
The user is presented with a series of "panels" that control numeric parameters and program operation via an intuitive "point and clickt1 methodology, making the software easy to learn and operate.

div.head: SCALAR AND VECTOR FUNCTIONS
div.p: The Scalar and Vector Functions block reads the input data sets and allows the user to select from a wide variety of field functions that can be applied to the solution data to calculate derived Vorticityll .

An integral register structure holds the results of the field calculations as three quantities per node point: a scalar value, a vector and a "threshold function". The threshold function may be used as a discriminator: scalar or vector functions will be displayed only where the threshold function is within a range specified by the user. In this way, the user can filter out parts of the display based on the value of a function.

div.head: NUMERIC TO GEOMETRIC FILTER
div.p: This functional block is the heart of the visualization process: it is here that the field data is converted into a "graphical paradym" for display. The user defines a set of surfaces, each with its own set of rendering parameters. A arbitrary cutting plane may be positioned interactively within the data field and the system will solve for the scalar and/or vector parameters on that plane. Iso-surfaces are defined by specifying a data value (or in the case of sweeping or animation, a range of values). FIELDVIEW will solve for the polygons required to generate the 3D iso-surface(s).

div.head: Both surface
div.p: control panels provide control over the rendering and colormap attributes used to display the results. Some of the rendering attributes that may be controlled are: representation (wireframe, shaded, shaded with light source) , visibility (on/off) , mesh display (on/off), and color. Colormap functions allow the user to interactively select from a list of predefined colormaps, squeeze/stretch the range and load user supplied colormaps.

div.head: VIEWING INTERFACE
div.p: The final stage in the Visualization Pipeline is the Viewing Interface. The user can rotate, zoom and move around the field to get a clearer picture of the flow.

div.head: RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
div.p: Three problems are used to demonstrate the use of FIELDVIEW in investigating flow data sets:
Numerical simulations [l] of hot supersonic exhaust jets produced from three nozzle designs;
A numerical simulation of the effect of a hot streak in a two-dimensional time-dependent rotor-stator interaction

div.head: HOT STREAK EXHAUST JETS
div.p: An interesting problem in aircraft applications is that of improving mixing rates of jet exhausts with the external streams.

This example uses results obtained by Anderson and Barber [l] in applying their three-dimensional paf-abolic Navier-Stokes procedure to a series of supersonic nozzles. A computational grid of approximately 190,000 grid points was used in the analysis of three configurations: axisymmetric, rectangular and splayed nozzles. analysis is to examine the splayed nozzle for enhanced mixing of exhaust over the other two configurations. Figure 2 shows axial cross sectional planes of total temperature. This type of display can be generated through the explicit selection of the computational plane location, or animated by sweeping the plane through a range. Figure 3 shows the 1000 degree Rankin isotherm for each of the three configurations.
It is clear from ,the visualization that the splayed mixer exhibits a more rapid mix out of hot exhaust gases.
The objective of the 3.2

div.head: HOT STREAK MIRGATION
div.p: In optimizing gas turbine cycle efficiency, it is desirable to achieve high average combuster exit temperatures. Due to the spatial and temporal varations in the exit flow temperatures, allowable metal temperature may be exceeded. Davis (UTRC) has applied a time-dependent, thin-layer Navier-Stokes method developed by Rai [5] to study the hot streak migration through a rotor-stator interaction. A configuration consisting of 3 stators and 4 rotors was analyzed with a multi-zone grid of approximately 35,000 node points. Figure 4 shows a single time step in the computation. The low temperature is indicated by the blue color and the high temperature is indicated by the red color.
The visualization clearly shows a build-up of hot streak on the pressure side of the rotor which leads to degradation of durability because of the high heat transfer.

div.head: FUEL INJECTOR
div.p: Experimental data can benefit from interactive analysis as well.
In this example, laser diffraction velocimetry (LDV) was used to measure the mean velocity flow field behind a Pratt and Whitney fuel injector [4].
The objective of the researchers was to understand the recirculation zone, a region in which the fluid in the opposite direction to the main flow.

Streamlines (or particle path lines) are used to understand this type of phenomena. Figure 5 shows a single view of the injector geometry and the streamlines. The streamlines are constructed by interactively releasing particles from a rake geometry.
FIELDVIEW calculates the resulting path taken by the particles at discrete time steps. The streamlines are colored to indicate the distance of the release point from the central axis of the injector.
When animation is used to display the particle motion, the experimentalists observed flow behavior near the boundary of the recirculation region that they were not aware of before.
In this case, interactive visualization was used to discover new physical phenomenon.

div.head: CONCLUSION
div.p: Fluid mechanics data sets generated by today's three-dimensional, time-dependent problems often contain billions of pieces of information.

These data sets may be effectively studied through the use of interactive data visualization to: FIELDVIEW is a software tool that has been created specifically to fulfill these criteria and as such, provides a very useful tool for interactive investigation of fluid mechanics data sets.

div.head: ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS
div.p: The author would like to thank Mr. David Edwards, Head of the Visualization Laboratory for his permission to use previous reference works and for his invaluable work on the VISA and FIELDVIEW projects.
In addition, the author expresses his gratitude to Drs. M. J.
Werle (UTC) , J. E. Carter (UTRC) for their support of Visualization, and Ms. Jeanne L. Mara (IL) for her assistance in producing this paper.
